formal_accuser.name: Claudatte wife of Simon Colas Toussainct Chailley

confession.seduction_context: Met Napnel 6 months before trial, angry about losing animals; devil offered to help find them if he renounced God. Refused at first but was beaten, then consented. Found animals where told. Devil then reminded him he had wished daughter to devil when in temper.

testimony.quarrel_subject: Working in cellar as salpetrier, accused and wife were not pleased

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: immediately after eating cheese on mardy gras

testimony.quarrel_subject: Son quarreled with Gregoire's son who beat him; witness complained to Gregoire and called him old witch. Later quarrel after acting as marriage intermediary.

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: after first quarrel (4 years before trial)
after second quarrel (about 3 years before trial)

testimony.quarrel_subject: Dispute returning from market; witness was provoked and punched accused until he bled

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: after accused pretended to be ill next day

testimony.quarrel_subject: Oak tree near Gregoire's garden whose shade prevented fruit trees; accused wanted to buy and cut it down but community refused

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: after community refused to let him cut tree

timeline.subject: Claudatte wife of Simon Chailley
timeline.details: Daughter Claudatte (imprisoned at Lusse) confessed previous day to being witch; today confessed father seduced her and took her to sabbat

timeline.subject: Claudatte and Gregoire Mathiel
timeline.details: Claudatte confronted with arrested father; warned of perjury dangers but maintained accusation. Father warned her she would damn herself but she did not waver and he fell silent

timeline.subject: Gregoire Mathiel
timeline.details: First interrogation; briefly admitted taking daughter to sabbat, then backtracked saying he only told her to go to devil when angry. Sent back to prison to think overnight

timeline.subject: Gregoire Mathiel
timeline.details: Called daughter foolish and ill-advised; claimed to be good Christian; requested legal counsel but denied

timeline.subject: Gregoire Mathiel
timeline.details: Confronted with witnesses; denied specific charges but made no reproaches

timeline.subject: Gregoire Mathiel
timeline.details: Procureur d'office for Chapter asks for torture

timeline.subject: Gregoire Mathiel
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture; persisted in denials under thumbscrews, confessed when racked. Full confession to seduction, sabbat attendance, receiving powder, killing animals

timeline.subject: Gregoire Mathiel
timeline.details: Confirmed confessions; said he had tried many times to escape devil's power, even went on pilgrimage to Saint Claude de Coniche but nothing worked

timeline.subject: Gregoire Mathiel
timeline.details: Repeated confessions; confronted with Jean Goniel (himself in prison) and maintained accusation despite denials

timeline.subject: Gregoire Mathiel
timeline.details: Procureur d'office asks for death sentence

timeline.subject: Gregoire Mathiel
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves death sentence

timeline.subject: Gregoire Mathiel
timeline.details: Formal death sentence from court at St Dié

accomplices_named.name: widow of Demenge Collatte (wife of Colas Collatte)
Jean Gomel (Goniel/Gounel)
accomplices_named.context: Uncle (serorge), seen at sabbat; confronted while in prison and denied

accomplices_named.name: Catherine wife of Claude Didier Laisne
la Petrematte wife of Jean le Maire

prior_accusations.context: Daughter confessed May 26, 1593 that father had seduced her and taken her to sabbat; maintained accusation in confrontation June 1, 1595

notable_quotes.speaker: Gregoire Mathiel to daughter Claudatte
notable_quotes.french: que sy le faict arrivoit sy avant qu'elle fut desmembrée par la justice, sy son marit ne vouloit la recepvoir, il la nourriroit luy mesme
notable_quotes.english: if matters went so far that she was dismembered by justice, if her husband would not receive her, he would nourish her himself
notable_quotes.context: Gregoire telling witness George Napuel what he said to his arrested daughter about supporting her even if convicted

notable_quotes.speaker: la devineresse de Tanviller
notable_quotes.french: qu'il avoit bien courroucé une femme, laquelle luy avoit causé ceste maladie
notable_quotes.english: that he had greatly angered a woman, who had caused him this illness
notable_quotes.context: Diviner/cunning woman's diagnosis of Jean Thiebauld Michiel's illness after eating cheese

notable_quotes.speaker: Gregoire Mathiel
notable_quotes.french: luy mesme a perdu plusieurs bestialz, et ne scait comme telle perte peult arriver
notable_quotes.english: he himself has lost several beasts, and does not know how such loss can happen
notable_quotes.context: Defending himself against accusations of causing animal deaths

notable_quotes.speaker: Judges' observation
notable_quotes.french: qu'il ne se vouloit laisser tourmenter, et que plustost diroit il ce dont il seroit enquis
notable_quotes.english: that he did not want to let himself be tormented, and that he would rather say what he was asked about
notable_quotes.context: Judges noting Gregoire had previously said he would confess rather than be tortured, but then persisted in denials

notable_quotes.speaker: Judges' observation
notable_quotes.french: et nous a faict veoir qu'il estoit fort bourrelé en sa conscience
notable_quotes.english: and he showed us that he was greatly tormented in his conscience
notable_quotes.context: Judges observing Gregoire's state before beginning torture

notable_quotes.speaker: Gregoire Mathiel
notable_quotes.french: Son intention fut plusieurs fois, ensuivent de grande repentance, qu'il avoit d'estre ainsy abusé, de le delaisser et se retirer de sa puissance, mesmes fut en pelerinage sans parler, a Sainct Claude de Coniche. Mais rien n'y valut, et sy jamais ne peult s'en detrapper.
notable_quotes.english: His intention was many times, following great repentance he had for being thus abused, to leave him and withdraw from his power, he even went on pilgrimage without speaking to Saint Claude de Coniche. But nothing availed, and he could never escape from it.
notable_quotes.context: Gregoire describing his attempts to escape the devil's power after confessing

relationships.evidence_text: Claudatte wife of Simon Colas Toussainct Chailley
Jean Gomel and Mengeatte his wife
Catherine wife of Claude Didier Laisne
working as servant to salpetrier in the prévôté, working in cellar of Gregoire's house
witness acted as intermediary for daughter's marriage
oak tree near Gregoire's garden, cow of his neighbour Jean Didier Cunin
killed calf belonging to his son Jean
la Petrematte of Lusse, wife of Jean le Maire

economic_context.details: Oak tree dispute: Gregoire wanted to buy and cut down valuable oak tree near his garden because its shade prevented him growing fruit trees. Community refused because acorns were valuable to all. Tree later struck by lightning, attributed to Gregoire's witchcraft.

harms_catalog.harm_description: became very ill, especially in legs, had to be carried back to father's house
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: working in cellar as salpetrier, they were not pleased
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: as soon as he ate cheese given on mardy gras

harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: son quarreled with Gregoire's son who beat him; witness complained and called Gregoire old witch
after acting as marriage intermediary, had another quarrel and again called him witch

harms_catalog.harm_description: lost a number of valuable beasts
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: dispute returning from market; witness punched Gregoire until he bled
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: after Gregoire pretended to be ill next day

harms_catalog.harm_description: struck by lightning and split down the centre when no other trees touched
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: wanted to buy and cut tree to prevent shade on his garden; community refused
son not content with what Gregoire had given him

harms_catalog.method_alleged: black powder, then cured with another powder from master

material_culture.context: Wife promised cheese to salpetrier, then son brought piece on mardy gras which made him ill when eaten
Devil gave Gregoire black powder to kill animals; tested on cat and horse first
Devil gave different powder to cure salpetrier after making him ill with black powder

material_culture.object: contrepoison made with herbs and roots
material_culture.context: Cunning woman (devineresse) of Tanviller gave to salpetrier to cure bewitchment
Community refused to let Gregoire cut oak tree because acorns were valuable to all

spatial_references.context: Main location of trial; residence of accused and several witnesses
Residence of daughter Claudatte after marriage; where Gregoire visited her in prison
Home of several alleged sabbat attendees (Jehenne Napuel, widow of Demenge Collatte)
Home of Catherine wife of Claude Didier Laisne, allegedly seen at sabbat
Home of witness Jean Thiebauld Michiel
Market location where Gregoire and George Napuel traveled
Home of la devineresse (cunning woman) consulted for counter-magic
Where daughter Claudatte was imprisoned; home of la Petrematte
Court that issued formal death sentence
Pilgrimage site where Gregoire went silently trying to escape devil's power
Disputed tree struck by lightning; shade prevented Gregoire growing fruit trees
Where salpetrier Jean Thiebauld Michiel worked
Where Gregoire and Claude le Clerc were returning from when they quarreled

economic_hardship_indicators: loss of animals described as significant economic harm

officials_named.name: substitut of procureur général de Lorraine

legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: imprisoned; exhorted to think overnight before next interrogation

hearsay_chains.content: Gregoire told witness what he said to his daughter about supporting her if convicted

emotional_state_notes: appeared greatly tormented in conscience before torture
silent after daughter would not waver in accusation
showed great repentance for being abused by devil

third_parties.name: Gregoire's wife
third_parties.context: Promised cheese to salpetrier; long reputed witch along with husband; son brought cheese on mardy gras

third_parties.name: Gregoire's son (who fought)
third_parties.context: Quarreled with Jean Didier le Marchal's son and beat him; brought cheese to salpetrier on mardy gras

third_parties.name: Jean Didier le Marchal's son
third_parties.context: Quarreled with Gregoire's son who was bigger and beat him

third_parties.name: Simon Chailley
third_parties.context: Sought Gregoire's daughter Claudatte in marriage; witness Jean Didier le Marchal acted as intermediary

third_parties.name: la devineresse de Tanviller
third_parties.context: Cunning woman/diviner consulted by salpetrier to diagnose and cure bewitchment; said he had angered a woman who caused illness; gave counterpoison of herbs and roots

third_parties.name: Jean Thiebauld Michiel's father
third_parties.context: Salpetrier was carried back to father's house after illness

third_parties.name: Jean (son of Gregoire)
third_parties.context: Gregoire confessed to killing his son's calf because son was not content with what he had given him

third_parties.name: Jean Goniel/Gounel
third_parties.context: Named as accomplice at sabbat; confronted while in prison and denied accusations

third_parties.name: Catherine wife of Claude Didier Laisne
la vieille Oursatte
third_parties.context: Named as accomplice at sabbat; already dead

third_parties.name: Jehenne du Fain
third_parties.context: Named as accomplice at sabbat; already dead

third_parties.name: la Petrematte wife of Jean le Maire
third_parties.context: Named as accomplice at sabbat; already dead

third_parties.name: daughter of Jean Aulbert
third_parties.context: Named as accomplice at sabbat; already dead

extraction_metadata.notes: Trial has unusual feature of 2-year gap between daughter's initial accusation (May 26, 1593) and father's arrest/trial (May-July 1595). Daughter was imprisoned at Lusse during father's trial. Gregoire initially briefly admitted then backtracked, only confessing fully under torture (rack). Notable detail about seeking to escape devil through pilgrimage to Saint Claude de Coniche. Jean Gomel/Goniel spelling varies (also 'serorge' which may be uncle/relative). Witness 6 is duplicate of witness 2 (both Jean Didier le Marchal, 50, Bertrimoutier) testifying to oak tree story. Economic status assessed as 'middling' based on: laboureur occupation, owned house with cellar, had garden, owned multiple animals (cat, horses, etc.), resided 30 years, but also experienced animal losses suggesting not wealthy.
